contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox publisher | image = <gallery> File:New_Writers'_Press_logo.jpg| </gallery> | parent = | status = | founded = 1967 | founder = [[Michael Smith (poet)|Michael Smith]] and [[Trevor Joyce]] | successor = | country = [[Ireland]] | headquarters = [[Dublin]] | distribution = | keypeople = | publications = [[Book]]s | topics = | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = }} '''New Writers' Press''' is an [[Ireland|Irish]] small [[Printing press|press]] that specialises in [[poetry]] [[publishing]]. The press was founded in 1967 by the [[poet]]s [[Michael Smith (poet)|Michael Smith]] and [[Trevor Joyce]] and Smith's wife [[Irene Smith (publisher)|Irene]] in response to what they felt to be the stagnant state of [[Irish poetry]] at the time. The first volume published by the Press was Joyceâ€™s debut collection, "Sole Glum Trek", which included an editorial by Smith that communicated the purpose of the Press as follows: :: [T]o bring out a series of small books each of which will give a young poet the chance of finding the audience so necessary to him ... :: Most of the poets whose work will be included in this series are Irish and under thirty. Believing poets should be beyond the herd :: instinct, they belong to no school, movement, club or clique. They are all serious poets, that is, human beings for whom writing poetry :: is morally, a profoundly central activity, not a mere hobby or ornamental grace. (Joyce, 1995: 277) The press was very active for the first 12 years of its existence, publishing some 46 items, including the six issues of the journal ''[[The Lace Curtain]]''. Since 1979, there have been approximately 12 new titles, some of them in collaboration with [[United Kingdom|British]], Canadian and Polish small press publishers. The press was committed to help revive interest in the [[Modernist poetry|modernist]] tradition in Irish poetry, and to this end they published [[Thomas MacGreevy]]'s ''Collected Poems'', [[Brian Coffey]]'s ''Selected Poems'' and a special 1930s issue of the journal, all in 1971. In addition to work by Coffey, MacGreevy, Joyce and Smith, New Writers Press authors included [[John Jordan]], [[Anthony Cronin]], [[Michael Hartnett (poet)|Michael Hartnett]], [[Augustus Young]], [[Jack Spicer]], [[Tom MacIntyre]], [[Patrick Galvin]], [[Paul Durcan]], Robert Pawlowski, and [[Antonio Machado]] (in Smith's translation). ==Notable titles== ''Poems''.
